segment.source: User Account Control Admin Approval Mode for the Built-in Administrator account (Windows 10)
segment.target: User Account Control Admin Approval Mode for the Built-in Administrator account (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the User Account Control Admin Approval Mode for the Built-in Administrator account security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the User Account Control Admin Approval Mode for the Built-in Administrator account security policy setting.

segment.source: User Account Control: Admin Approval Mode for the Built-in Administrator account
segment.target: User Account Control: Admin Approval Mode for the Built-in Administrator account

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the User Account Control: Admin Approval Mode for the Built-in Administrator account security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the User Account Control: Admin Approval Mode for the Built-in Administrator account security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines the behavior of Admin Approval Mode for the built-in administrator account.
segment.target: This policy setting determines the behavior of Admin Approval Mode for the built-in administrator account.

segment.source: When the Admin Approval Mode is enabled, the local administrator account functions like a standard user account, but it has the ability to elevate privileges without logging on by using a different account.
segment.target: When the Admin Approval Mode is enabled, the local administrator account functions like a standard user account, but it has the ability to elevate privileges without logging on by using a different account.

segment.source: In this mode, any operation that requires elevation of privilege displays a prompt that allows the administrator to permit or deny the elevation of privilege.
segment.target: In this mode, any operation that requires elevation of privilege displays a prompt that allows the administrator to permit or deny the elevation of privilege.

segment.source: If Admin Approval Mode is not enabled, the built-in Administrator account logs on in Windows XP Mode, and it runs all applications by default with full administrative privileges.
segment.target: If Admin Approval Mode is not enabled, the built-in Administrator account logs on in Windows XP Mode, and it runs all applications by default with full administrative privileges.

segment.source: By default, this setting is set to Disabled.
segment.target: By default, this setting is set to Disabled.

segment.source: Note: If a computer is upgraded from a previous version of the Windows operating system, and the administrator account is the only account on the computer, the built-in administrator account remains enabled, and this setting is also enabled.
segment.target: Note: If a computer is upgraded from a previous version of the Windows operating system, and the administrator account is the only account on the computer, the built-in administrator account remains enabled, and this setting is also enabled.

segment.source: The built-in administrator account logs on in Admin Approval Mode so that any operation that requires elevation of privilege displays a prompt that provides the administrator the option to permit or deny the elevation of privilege.
segment.target: The built-in administrator account logs on in Admin Approval Mode so that any operation that requires elevation of privilege displays a prompt that provides the administrator the option to permit or deny the elevation of privilege.

segment.source: The built-in administrator account logs on in Windows XP Mode, and it runs all applications by default with full administrative privileges.
segment.target: The built-in administrator account logs on in Windows XP Mode, and it runs all applications by default with full administrative privileges.

segment.source: Do not enable the built-in administrator account on the client computer, but use the standard user account and User Account Control (UAC).
segment.target: Do not enable the built-in administrator account on the client computer, but use the standard user account and User Account Control (UAC).

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: One of the risks of the User Account Control (UAC) feature is that it is intended to mitigate malicious software running under elevated credentials without the user or administrator being aware of its activity.
segment.target: One of the risks of the User Account Control (UAC) feature is that it is intended to mitigate malicious software running under elevated credentials without the user or administrator being aware of its activity.

segment.source: An attack vector for malicious programs is to discover the password of the administrator account because that user account was created for all installations of the Windows.
segment.target: An attack vector for malicious programs is to discover the password of the administrator account because that user account was created for all installations of the Windows.

segment.source: To address this risk, the built-in administrator account is disabled in computers running at least Windows Vista.
segment.target: To address this risk, the built-in administrator account is disabled in computers running at least Windows Vista.

segment.source: In computers running at least Windows Server 2008, the administrator account is enabled, and the password must be changed the first time the Administrator logs on.
segment.target: In computers running at least Windows Server 2008, the administrator account is enabled, and the password must be changed the first time the Administrator logs on.

segment.source: In a default installation of a computer running at least Windows Vista, accounts with administrative control over the computer are initially set up in one of two ways:
segment.target: In a default installation of a computer running at least Windows Vista, accounts with administrative control over the computer are initially set up in one of two ways:

segment.source: If the computer is not joined to a domain, the first user account you create has the equivalent permissions as a local administrator.
segment.target: If the computer is not joined to a domain, the first user account you create has the equivalent permissions as a local administrator.

segment.source: If the computer is joined to a domain, no local administrator accounts are created.
segment.target: If the computer is joined to a domain, no local administrator accounts are created.

segment.source: The enterprise or domain administrator must log on to the computer and create a local administrator account if one is warranted.
segment.target: The enterprise or domain administrator must log on to the computer and create a local administrator account if one is warranted.

segment.source: Enable the User Account Control: Admin Approval Mode for the Built-in Administrator account setting if you have the built-in Administrator account enabled.
segment.target: Enable the User Account Control: Admin Approval Mode for the Built-in Administrator account setting if you have the built-in Administrator account enabled.

segment.source: Users who log on by using the local administrator account are prompted for consent whenever a program requests an elevation in privilege.
segment.target: Users who log on by using the local administrator account are prompted for consent whenever a program requests an elevation in privilege.
